channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Venezuelans describe the day after U.S. strikes
item.description: A day after Saturday's U.S. strikes, Venezuelans describe fear, confusion, and long lines for fuel and food.
item.content:encoded: A day after Saturday's U.S. strikes, Venezuelans describe fear, confusion, and long lines for fuel and food.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Covering US-Russian relations and a rapidly changing wartime Russia
item.description: NPR's Charles Maynes in Moscow on how the White House's Russia rhetoric shifted this year and how it is landing in Moscow.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Charles Maynes in Moscow on how the White House's Russia rhetoric shifted this year and how it is landing in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Understanding how a warming climate might affect a crucial ocean current
item.description: Climate change is warming Europe, but scientists are also studying whether a weakened Atlantic current could make Britain colder, with Laurie Laybourne, director of the Strategic Climate Risks Initiative in southwest England.
item.content:encoded: Climate change is warming Europe, but scientists are also studying whether a weakened Atlantic current could make Britain colder, with Laurie Laybourne, director of the Strategic Climate Risks Initiative in southwest England.
item.dc:creator: Gurjit Kaur

item.title: 'The Definitions' novel takes a haunting look at identity, language and control
item.description: Author Matt Greene on his new dystopian novel 'The Definitions' about life after a virus wipes people's memories.
item.content:encoded: Author Matt Greene on his new dystopian novel 'The Definitions' about life after a virus wipes people's memories.
item.dc:creator: Justine Kenin

item.title: Even in prison, Marwan Barghouthi looms large in Palestinian politics
item.description: Arab Barghouthi, the son of Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouthi, on his father's life in Israeli prison and the stalemate after nearly two decades without elections.
item.content:encoded: Arab Barghouthi, the son of Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouthi, on his father's life in Israeli prison and the stalemate after nearly two decades without elections.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: A year after the LA fires, finding the sounds that make a home
item.description: A personal essay about the silence after the Los Angeles fires and what it means to hear music again, by 18 year old Zacharie Sergenian for NPR member station KCRW.
item.content:encoded: A personal essay about the silence after the Los Angeles fires and what it means to hear music again, by 18 year old Zacharie Sergenian for NPR member station KCRW.
item.dc:creator: Zacharie Sergenian

item.title: New details emerging on how the White House intends to run Venezuela
item.description: A day after the operation in Venezuela, the White House is clarifying what running the country means, as Congress splits sharply along party lines.
item.content:encoded: A day after the operation in Venezuela, the White House is clarifying what running the country means, as Congress splits sharply along party lines.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Who's in charge in Venezuela now?
item.description: Who is in charge in Venezuela after the US seized and ousted its president? Manuel Rueda reports from Bogotá, Colombia.
item.content:encoded: Who is in charge in Venezuela after the US seized and ousted its president? Manuel Rueda reports from Bogotá, Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Rueda

item.title: Trump wants U.S. oil companies in Venezuela. Here's what to know
item.description: President Trump wants more U.S. oil companies to "go in" to Venezuela. But there are economic, historical, and climate reasons that may not be easy. Here's what you need to know about oil in Venezuela.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump wants more U.S. oil companies to "go in" to Venezuela. But there are economic, historical, and climate reasons that may not be easy. Here's what you need to know about oil in Venezuela.

(Image credit: Matias Delacroix)
item.dc:creator: Julia Simon

item.title: Can the U.S. claim a law-enforcement justification for entering Venezuela?
item.description: Scott Anderson, an international law expert at the Brookings Institution, weighs the legal case for the U.S. operation in Venezuela.
item.content:encoded: Scott Anderson, an international law expert at the Brookings Institution, weighs the legal case for the U.S. operation in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen
